Package org.numpy4j.core

Class NDArray

java.lang.Object
org.numpy4j.core.NDArray
public class NDArray extends Object
A lightweight, high-performance Java implementation of a multidimensional array, inspired by Python's NumPy ndarray.

NDArray provides efficient storage and operations for numerical computing, including element-wise arithmetic, slicing, reshaping, matrix multiplication, broadcasting, and statistical methods.
It is designed as part of the numpy4j project â€” a Java library bringing the expressiveness of NumPy to the JVM ecosystem.

Key Features

  • Support for arbitrary-dimensional arrays
  • Element-wise arithmetic operations
  • Automatic broadcasting (similar to NumPy)
  • Reshape, slice, transpose, and power operations
  • Matrix multiplication via dot(NDArray)
  • Statistical methods such as sum() and mean()

Example Usage


 // Create arrays
 NDArray a = NDArray.ones(2, 3);
 NDArray b = NDArray.arange(0, 6, 1).reshape(2, 3);

 // Perform operations
 NDArray c = a.add(b);
 NDArray d = c.power(2);
 NDArray e = d.dot(NDArray.eye(3));

 System.out.println("Sum: " + e.sum());
 System.out.println("Mean: " + e.mean());

The internal data is stored as a flat double[] for efficiency, and all operations are implemented in pure Java with optional multithreading. Future versions may integrate with OpenBLAS or Intel MKL for native performance.

Since:
2025

    • reshape

      public NDArray reshape(int... newShape)
      Returns a new NDArray with the same data but a different shape.

      This method behaves like numpy.reshape() in Python. It does not modify the original array but creates a view-like copy with the specified dimensions. The total number of elements must remain constant.

      Example:

      
 NDArray a = NDArray.arange(0, 6, 1);  // shape (6,)
 NDArray b = a.reshape(2, 3);          // shape (2, 3)

 System.out.println(Arrays.toString(a.getShape())); // [6]
 System.out.println(Arrays.toString(b.getShape())); // [2, 3]
      Parameters:
      newShape - the target dimensions for the new array (e.g., (2, 3))
      Returns:
      a reshaped NDArray containing the same data
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the total number of elements differs

    • sum

      public double sum()
      Computes the sum of all elements in the NDArray.
      Returns:
      the sum of all elements

    • mean

      public double mean()
      Computes the mean (average) of all elements in the NDArray.
      Returns:
      the mean value

    • power

      public NDArray power(int exponent)
      Raises each element to the given power.
      Parameters:
      exponent - the exponent to apply
      Returns:
      a new NDArray with each element raised to exponent

    • slice

      public NDArray slice(int[][] indices)
      Extracts a subarray (slice) from this NDArray, similar to numpy[:, :] slicing in Python.

      Currently supports 2D arrays only. The slice indices are specified as a 2D array of start and end indices per dimension.

      Example:

      
 NDArray a = new NDArray(new double[]{
     1, 2, 3,
     4, 5, 6,
     7, 8, 9
 }, 3, 3);

 // Slice rows 0â€“2 (exclusive of 2), columns 1â€“3 (exclusive of 3)
 NDArray b = a.slice(new int[][]{{0, 2}, {1, 3}});

 // Result:
 // [[2.0, 3.0],
 //  [5.0, 6.0]]
      Parameters:
      indices - a 2D array defining start and end indices for each dimension, e.g. {{rowStart, rowEnd}, {colStart, colEnd}}
      Returns:
      a new NDArray representing the requested slice
      Throws:
      IllegalArgumentException - if the indices are invalid
      UnsupportedOperationException - if the array is not 2D

    • dot

      public NDArray dot(NDArray other)
      Computes the matrix dot product between this array and another.

      This method is equivalent to numpy.dot() for 2D arrays (matrices). It performs standard matrix multiplication: if this is of shape (m, n) and other is of shape (n, p), the result will have shape (m, p).

      Example:

      
 NDArray a = new NDArray(new double[]{1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6}, 2, 3);
 NDArray b = new NDArray(new double[]{7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12}, 3, 2);
 NDArray c = a.dot(b);

 // Result:
 // [[58.0, 64.0],
 //  [139.0, 154.0]]

 System.out.println(Arrays.toString(c.getShape())); // [2, 2]
      Parameters:
      other - another NDArray to multiply with this one
      Returns:
      the resulting NDArray after matrix multiplication
      Throws:
      UnsupportedOperationException - if either array is not 2D
      IllegalArgumentException - if the inner dimensions do not match
